content: How can I help you today?

I’ve been having trouble sleeping lately, and it’s starting to feel like it’s affecting everything. My work has been really stressful, and I can’t stop worrying about what might happen. The nights are just filled with constant thoughts running through my head, and I don’t know how to calm them down. My partner thought maybe talking to someone might help, so here I am.

That sounds really overwhelming, and it’s understandable that constant worrying and sleepless nights would start to take a toll. It’s great that your partner encouraged you to reach out, and you're taking steps to explore what might help. What do you feel is making it hardest for you to calm your thoughts when you try to sleep?

It’s mostly the stress from work and feeling like I might get fired. I keep thinking about what I could’ve done differently or how to fix things, and then I get lost in that spiral. It feels like no matter what I try, I’m just stuck in the same loop every night.

It sounds like the fear of losing your job and replaying past decisions is really weighing on you. It can be tough when those worries keep circling in your mind and don’t seem to stop, especially when you’re trying to rest. Despite feeling stuck, you’re reflecting on what’s happening, which is a big step. What, if anything, have you tried to help yourself cope or find relief from the worrying?

I usually try to distract myself by scrolling on my phone, but honestly, it just adds more thoughts to the mix and keeps me awake even longer. I’ve tried lying still and closing my eyes, but that just makes the thoughts louder. I don’t really know what else I could do.

It sounds frustrating that the distractions you’ve tried only seem to make things harder for you, and lying still amplifies the thoughts you’re trying to quiet. It seems like you’re searching for a way to break free from the cycle but feeling unsure about where to start. What do you think could help you feel a little more peaceful in those moments before you sleep?

It’s hard to say what could really help in the moment. Maybe if I wasn’t so stressed during the day, I’d be able to settle down at night. But right now, I don’t even know how to handle the stress I feel, let alone calm down before bed. I’m kind of out of ideas.

It sounds like the stress from the day is carrying over into your nights, making it harder to find calm. Feeling out of ideas can be discouraging, but recognizing that stress during the day might be the key is an important insight. What would it mean for you to feel more in control of the stress you experience during the day?

I think if I could feel less overwhelmed and more confident about what I’m doing at work, it would help a lot. Right now, I just feel like I’m barely holding it together, and that pressure follows me everywhere. If I felt more stable there, maybe I wouldn’t be so anxious all the time.

It sounds like building a sense of stability and confidence at work could be really important for easing some of the pressure you’re feeling. That constant sense of overwhelm can be so draining, especially when it lingers even outside of work. You’ve been managing a lot, and it seems you’re also thinking about what could make things better. If you picture things being less overwhelming, what would that look like for you?

I guess it would look like feeling more on top of tasks at work, like I know what’s expected and I’m actually meeting those expectations. It would mean not constantly second-guessing myself or worrying about what my boss thinks. Maybe then I could leave work at work and not bring it home with me every night.

It sounds like having clarity about your tasks and feeling capable of meeting expectations could be a big step toward reducing the worry that follows you home. Leaving work at work and having space to unwind sounds like something you’d really value in your life. What do you feel might help you take steps toward that sense of confidence and separation between work and home?

It’s hard to say. Maybe better communication with my boss about expectations could help, but I’m nervous about bringing up anything that might make them think I’m struggling. I don’t want to make things worse by drawing attention to it. At the same time, I know I can’t keep this up forever.

Balancing the desire to improve communication while worrying about how it might be perceived is definitely tough, especially when you’re already feeling under pressure. It sounds like you’re recognizing the need for change while trying to figure out how to approach it in a way that feels safe for you. Would you feel comfortable exploring small actions you could take to gain clarity or support without feeling like you’re risking too much?

I’m not really sure where to start, but maybe if I could find a way to bring up my concerns casually, it wouldn’t feel so risky. Like, maybe I could ask for feedback on my work or check in about priorities without making it a big deal. It’s just hard to take that first step when I already feel so on edge.

Thinking about ways to bring it up casually, like asking for feedback or checking in on priorities, sounds like a thoughtful approach that might help without adding extra stress. It’s understandable that taking the first step feels hard when you’re already feeling on edge. Giving yourself permission to start small might ease some of that pressure. How do you imagine it would feel to try one of those actions?

Honestly, I think it would feel uncomfortable at first, but maybe it could help me feel a little more clear on where I stand. If it went well, it might take some of the guesswork out of things, which could ease my mind. I’m just not great at speaking up, so it feels intimidating.

It makes sense that speaking up feels intimidating, especially when you’re already juggling so much stress. At the same time, it seems like you’re recognizing how clarity could begin easing some of the mental load you’re carrying. Even though it might feel uncomfortable at first, it sounds like you’re open to the possibility of growth. Is there anything that might make taking that step feel a little less daunting?

Maybe if I plan out what I want to say ahead of time, I’d feel a little more prepared. I could keep it really simple, like just asking for feedback on one specific project instead of trying to tackle everything at once. Baby steps might make it feel a little less overwhelming.

Planning ahead and starting with one specific project sounds like a thoughtful way to ease into the conversation. Taking baby steps could help you feel more prepared and make the process feel manageable. You’re breaking it down in a way that honors your comfort while still moving toward positive change. Is there anything else you’d want to include in your plan to make it feel even more doable?
